headline.main: Seeking Freedom and Security at a Time of War

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Civil Liberty vs. Security: Finding a Wartime Balance'' (front page, Nov. 18): In every modern war, victors have faced the question of how the vanquished will be held accountable. After World War II, the Allies held court before the world in Nuremberg and in Japan. Today, international courts are hearing cases arising from wars in the former Yugoslavia and in Rwanda. All these proceedings had two common elements: they represented multinational efforts at enforcing a rule of law, and they were public.
abstract: Letter from Irwin H Schwartz (National Association of Criminal Lawyers), commenting on Nov 18 article, urges Bush administation not to resort to secret courts and secret evidence in trying in prosecuting suspected terrorists
